questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after falling through the ice while skating on a frozen lake. He presents with confusion and disorientation. His temperature is 93.2°F, pulse is 120/min, and respirations are 22/min. Physical examination reveals cold, pale extremities, and numbness of the fingers. His blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Laboratory results show mildly elevated serum creatinine, normal electrolyte levels, and an increased urine output over the next several hours. Further evaluation reveals a decrease in serum antidiuretic hormone (ADH) levels. Which of the following additional findings would be most consistent with the underlying physiological mechanism of this patient’s presentation?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased renin release and aldosterone secretion

options.label: B
options.text: Elevated atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) due to central volume expansion

questions.correct_answer: B. Elevated atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) due to central volume expansion
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Elevated atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) due to central volume expansion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In hypothermia, cold-induced diuresis is driven by an increase in central blood volume due to peripheral vasoconstriction. This leads to elevated ANP levels, suppression of ADH, and increased urine production. Understanding these interrelated physiological changes is crucial in managing hypothermic patients.
  • ➤ In hypothermia, cold-induced diuresis is driven by an increase in central blood volume due to peripheral vasoconstriction.
  • ➤ This leads to elevated ANP levels, suppression of ADH, and increased urine production.
  • ➤ Understanding these interrelated physiological changes is crucial in managing hypothermic patients.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with progressive changes in her right eye, including blurred vision and an abnormal pupil position. After slit-lamp examination, the patient is diagnosed with Iridocorneal Endothelial (ICE) syndrome. Which of the following findings is not typically associated with ICE syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Iridocorneal Endothelial (ICE) syndrome is a rare ocular condition characterized by corectopia , iris atrophy , and corneal endothelial abnormalities. The exact mechanism is unknown, however there appears to be a component of abnormal corneal endothelium that proliferates onto the iris forming a membrane that then obstructs the trabecular meshwork, leading to iris distortion. Nodule formation can also occur when the abnormal corneal endothelium causes contractions around the iris stroma. Herpesvirus DNA has been identified in some patients following keratoplasty, suggesting the possibility that herpes simplex virus may induce the abnormal endothelialization in the anterior chamber angle and on the surface of the iris. Cataracts are not a typical feature of ICE syndrome, and distinguishing these findings is essential in recognizing and managing this rare disorder effectively.
  • ➤ Iridocorneal Endothelial (ICE) syndrome is a rare ocular condition characterized by corectopia , iris atrophy , and corneal endothelial abnormalities.
  • ➤ Iridocorneal Endothelial (ICE) syndrome
  • ➤ corectopia
  • ➤ iris atrophy
  • ➤ The exact mechanism is unknown, however there appears to be a component of abnormal corneal endothelium that proliferates onto the iris forming a membrane that then obstructs the trabecular meshwork, leading to iris distortion.
  • ➤ Nodule formation can also occur when the abnormal corneal endothelium causes contractions around the iris stroma.
  • ➤ Herpesvirus DNA has been identified in some patients following keratoplasty, suggesting the possibility that herpes simplex virus may induce the abnormal endothelialization in the anterior chamber angle and on the surface of the iris.
  • ➤ Cataracts are not a typical feature of ICE syndrome, and distinguishing these findings is essential in recognizing and managing this rare disorder effectively.
  • ➤ Cataracts

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with confusion and lethargy. Her history is significant for a recent episode of gastroenteritis, which led to decreased oral intake. Blood tests reveal significantly elevated ammonia levels. Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hyperammonemia leads to the depletion of α-ketoglutarate in the brain as ammonia is detoxified through its conversion to glutamine. This depletion disrupts the TCA cycle, reducing energy production in neurons and contributing to the neurotoxic effects of elevated ammonia levels, such as lethargy and confusion.
  • ➤ Hyperammonemia leads to the depletion of α-ketoglutarate in the brain as ammonia is detoxified through its conversion to glutamine.
  • ➤ This depletion disrupts the TCA cycle, reducing energy production in neurons and contributing to the neurotoxic effects of elevated ammonia levels, such as lethargy and confusion.

Treponema pallidum cannot be cultured in artificial media, and RPR is not used for CSF analysis .

  • • Explanation:
  • • Red (Immediate) : These patients have life-threatening injuries that require immediate intervention to survive (e.g., severe bleeding, airway compromise). Yellow (Delayed) : These patients have serious but non-life-threatening injuries. Treatment can be delayed without significant risk to life or limb (e.g., fractures, large wounds). Green (Minor) : These patients have minor injuries that can wait for extended periods before receiving treatment, or may not require treatment at all (e.g., small cuts, bruises). Black (Deceased/Expectant) : These individuals are either deceased or have injuries so severe that survival is not possible, even with immediate medical attention (e.g., massive head trauma, no pulse).

This adaptation conserves glucose for insulin-independent tissues, such as the brain and red blood cells.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a history of generalized anxiety disorder is being considered for a benzodiazepine to help manage her symptoms. questions.text: Match the following regarding the transmission of Japanese Encephalitis (JE):
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A-4, B-1, C-3, D-2

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Culex mosquitoes (A-4) act as the vector for the transmission of Japanese Encephalitis. They bite infected animals or birds and transmit the virus to humans and other animals. Man (B-1) is considered an accidental host in the lifecycle of the Japanese Encephalitis virus because humans do not develop sufficient viremia to infect mosquitoes, thus playing no role in the maintenance of the virus. Pigs (C-3) are considered the amplifier host because they develop a high viremia which helps to sustain and amplify the virus in the environment. Ardeid birds (D-2) (such as herons and egrets) serve as the reservoir hosts for Japanese Encephalitis, where the virus can persist in the natural environment.

  • • Man (B-1)
  • • accidental host
  • • Pigs (C-3) are considered the amplifier host because they develop a high viremia which helps to sustain and amplify the virus in the environment.
  • • Pigs (C-3)
  • • amplifier host
  • • Ardeid birds (D-2) (such as herons and egrets) serve as the reservoir hosts for Japanese Encephalitis, where the virus can persist in the natural environment.

questions.text: 65-year-old woman is evaluated during a routine check-up. She reports feeling well overall, with no significant symptoms other than mild fatigue. Physical examination is unremarkable. Routine laboratory tests reveal a hemoglobin level of 12.5 g/dL, calcium level of 9.2 mg/dL, and serum creatinine of 1.0 mg/dL. Serum protein electrophoresis identifies a monoclonal spike (M-spike) with an IgG concentration of 1.2 g/dL. Urine protein electrophoresis is negative for Bence Jones proteins. Bone marrow biopsy shows plasma cells comprising less than 10% of the total cellularity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: C. Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MGUS is an asymptomatic condition identified by the presence of a monoclonal protein in the blood, with a low M-spike, fewer than 10% plasma cells in the bone marrow, and no evidence of organ damage or other features of multiple myeloma.
  • ➤ MGUS is an asymptomatic condition identified by the presence of a monoclonal protein in the blood, with a low M-spike, fewer than 10% plasma cells in the bone marrow, and no evidence of organ damage or other features of multiple myeloma.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl presents with her mother, who is concerned about her child experiencing intense perianal itching, particularly at night. On further questioning, the mother also reports that her daughter is having difficulty sleeping and is being irritable. A stool sample examination was performed, and the egg was seen in the picture below . Which of the following is the most likely organism responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm) causes perianal itching , particularly at night. The eggs are elongated with a flattened side , and diagnosis can be made through stool microscopy or the Scotch tape test .

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents to the clinic with diffuse bone pain, primarily affecting her right arm and left thigh. She also reports worsening constipation and mild fatigue. On physical examination, there is tenderness over the left thigh. Laboratory tests reveal a serum calcium level of 13.2 mg/dL, phosphate level of 1.3 mg/dL, and creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL. Additional laboratory findings include an elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) level. A bone biopsy reveals cystic changes, fibrosis, and hemosiderin-laden macrophages. An X-ray of the left femur demonstrates subperiosteal bone resorption. Based on these findings, what is the most appropriate initial intervention to confirm the underlying cause of this patient's condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Obtain a skeletal survey to evaluate for multiple myeloma

options.label: C
options.text: Perform a breast ultrasound to screen for metastatic disease

options.label: D
options.text: Perform a parathyroid scintigraphy scan (Sestamibi scan)

questions.correct_answer: D. Perform a parathyroid scintigraphy scan (Sestamibi scan)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Primary hyperparathyroidism is a common cause of hypercalcemia with characteristic skeletal manifestations, including osteitis fibrosa cystica and subperiosteal bone resorption. The most definitive diagnostic step involves localization of a parathyroid adenoma, typically through parathyroid scintigraphy.
  • ➤ Primary hyperparathyroidism is a common cause of hypercalcemia with characteristic skeletal manifestations, including osteitis fibrosa cystica and subperiosteal bone resorption.
  • ➤ The most definitive diagnostic step involves localization of a parathyroid adenoma, typically through parathyroid scintigraphy.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with wrist drop and sensory loss over the dorsum of the hand after a humeral shaft fracture, suggesting a radial nerve injury. Which of the following statements about the radial nerve is most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Anconeus is supplied by a branch arising in the axilla.

options.label: B
options.text: The lateral head of the triceps is paralyzed in a lesion of the radial nerve in the lower spiral groove.

options.label: C
options.text: It leaves the axilla by passing through the quadrangular space.

options.label: D
options.text: In the arm, it travels along the brachial artery.

questions.correct_answer: B. The lateral head of the triceps is paralyzed in a lesion of the radial nerve in the lower spiral groove.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The radial nerve runs along the spiral groove of the humerus and can be injured in mid-shaft humeral fractures. Lesions in this area can cause paralysis of the lateral head of the triceps and wrist drop.
  • ➤ The radial nerve runs along the spiral groove of the humerus and can be injured in mid-shaft humeral fractures.
  • ➤ Lesions in this area can cause paralysis of the lateral head of the triceps and wrist drop.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is undergoing surgery to correct a congenital ptosis. The induction of anesthesia is smooth, and the procedure proceeds without complications. As the surgeon begins to manipulate the extraocular muscles, the anesthesiologist looks at the monitor. Why is the anesthesiologist doing this?

options.label: A
options.text: To check the depth of anesthesia

options.label: C
options.text: To see if there was bradycardia

options.label: D
options.text: To ensure there were no ventricular arrhythmias

questions.correct_answer: C. To see if there was bradycardia
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) To see if there was bradycardia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The oculocardiac reflex is a common occurrence during eye surgeries involving manipulation of the extraocular muscles, leading to bradycardia through the trigemino-vagal pathway . Awareness and prompt management are crucial to avoid severe complications during these procedures.
  • ➤ The oculocardiac reflex is a common occurrence during eye surgeries involving manipulation of the extraocular muscles, leading to bradycardia through the trigemino-vagal pathway .
  • ➤ oculocardiac reflex
  • ➤ bradycardia
  • ➤ trigemino-vagal pathway
  • ➤ Awareness and prompt management are crucial to avoid severe complications during these procedures.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with progressive muscle weakness and difficulty swallowing over the past 6 months. He also reports episodes of choking while eating and frequent coughing, particularly at night. On examination, there is spasticity in the lower limbs, hyperreflexia, and fasciculations in the tongue and arms. His speech is slurred, and there is notable muscle atrophy in the hands. Over time, his symptoms worsen, and he develops respiratory difficulty. Which of the following medications could slow the progression of his disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Riluzole

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Riluzole is an approved medication that can slow the progression of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) by reducing glutamate-induced neuronal damage.

questions.text: A 11-year-old boy presents to the clinic with small, raised, rough lesions on his hands and fingers. His mother reports that the lesions have been slowly increasing in number over the past several months. The child is otherwise healthy with no history of significant illness. On examination, the lesions are firm with a rough surface. What types of human papillomavirus (HPV) are most commonly associated with these cutaneous lesions?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Human papillomavirus types 2, 4, and 27 are the most common causes of cutaneous warts (verrucae vulgaris), especially on the hands and fingers. These warts are firm, raised, and rough-surfaced, and are often seen in children due to direct contact transmission of HPV.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with a 20-year history of poorly controlled type 1 diabetes presents with blurred vision and is found to have a developing cataract. Which of the following enzymes is most closely linked to the underlying mechanism in this patient's cataract condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aldose reductase plays a crucial role in the conversion of glucose to sorbitol in the polyol pathway, especially under hyperglycemic conditions. In patients with diabetes, the accumulation of sorbitol in tissues with limited sorbitol dehydrogenase activity can lead to osmotic stress, contributing to complications like cataract formation in the lens.
  • ➤ Aldose reductase plays a crucial role in the conversion of glucose to sorbitol in the polyol pathway, especially under hyperglycemic conditions.
  • ➤ In patients with diabetes, the accumulation of sorbitol in tissues with limited sorbitol dehydrogenase activity can lead to osmotic stress, contributing to complications like cataract formation in the lens.
